pr_title: Instrument Runnables/Callables instead of wrapping them

timeline.message:
Instrument Runnables/Callables instead of wrapping

closes #987
Fix for Executors that execute on current thread
Speed up tests by avoiding to call Mockito spy in hot method

timeline.bodyText: Obtain these two class lists outside the matching flow, otherwise Mockito has problems with the config mocks. See this comment.

replies.bodyText:
Also, if it's about identification of nesting only (without knowing the level of nesting), no need for a map - a stack of classes is sufficient.

Not quite sure what you mean by that. Note that often you also need to know in the exit advice whether it's a nested invocation.

If it's thread local, why using an AtomicInteger?

Mainly out of convenience. We could create something like a MultableInt to get rid of the volatile reads/writes if that's what you're hinting at?

Lastly, using class name may be better as it won't require weak referencing.

The new version is using a string which is important so the call depth is a global vs a per classloader counter.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText:
Note that often you also need to know in the exit advice whether it's a nested invocation.

Why isn't a stack enough for that? In any case, if you know in the enter advice, it should be easy to tell the exit advice...

Mainly out of convenience. We could create something like a MultableInt to get rid of the volatile reads/writes if that's what you're hinting at?

The volatile and the additional overhead of atomically fetching and incrementing/decrementing. Why does it have to be mutable and not an Integer you override when incrementing/decrementing? You would really need a deep nesting to be out of the Integer cache

The new version is using a string which is important so the call depth is a global vs a per classloader counter.

Do you think the usage of same class names loaded by different class loaders on the same stack is a concern?

timeline.bodyText: This introduces a risk of causing ClassCastException due to the collection type. I think it's better to try/catch using Collection.remove and Collection.add and avoid wrapping (with logging) if not supported by the collection.
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: That would impact the order of the callables in the collection. But we could clear and re-fill it.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: That's right. So either that, or avoid wrapping (meaning - not supporting lambdas in collections) if you feel it adds too much complexity.
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
I think calling add and remove is more likely to fail than creating an entirely new list because that's a good chance the collection is immutable.
Maybe leave as-is and remove if we see it causes problems?
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText:
My vote is actually to go the other way around - fail (meaning - don't wrap lambdas in collections if the collection is immutable) or not try to wrap in collections and see if we get requests to support that. I prefer questions about why something is not working than issues with breaking applications.
If you are not convinced - leave as is.
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
That may cause subtle context losses that are very hard to debug. I'd like to resort to these defensive measures only if there are actual problems in the wild which will surface in a more obvious way by throwing an exception. I'll add a new instrumentation group name executor-collection to disable just this instrumentation more easily.
I think in practice it's unlikely that an executor implementation depends on the type of the collection or even overrides the default implementation in AbstractExecutorService.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: This entire PR is about executors exposing APIs that allow interfaces but expect specific types 🙂
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: What about pooling wrappers? Could be used very frequently.
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: By putting the runnable in a WeakConcurrentMap, we're already allocating a WeakReference and a Map.Entry so pooling the Runnable wrapper won't make it allocation free, unfortunately. Given that, I don't think it's worth it.
